content.text: How far does logic extend? Does it govern all thought, all language, all reasoning? Or are there domains where logic doesn't apply? These questions define logic's philosophical scope.

Some argue logic is **universal** — any coherent thought must obey logical laws. You can't think a genuine contradiction. Others suggest some domains (art, emotion, religion) operate by different rules.

content.definition: The view that there are multiple, equally correct logics for different purposes or domains. Classical logic isn't the 'one true logic' — different contexts may require different logics.

content.title: Logic and Natural Language
premises: 'If you mow the lawn, I'll pay you $10'
Classical logic: the conditional is trivially true
Natural language: the offer no longer applies
content.note: Natural language 'if-then' doesn't always match material implication.

content.text: Is logic about language (linguistic), about thought (psychological), about abstract structures (mathematical), or about reality (metaphysical)? Each answer shapes how we understand logic's role.

Perhaps logic is best understood as a **normative** discipline — not describing how we think, but prescribing how we should think if we want to reason well. Logic provides standards for good inference.

content.question: What does logical pluralism claim?
options: There is only one correct logic
Different contexts may require different logics
content.explanation: Logical pluralists hold that there isn't one 'true logic' — different purposes (mathematics, everyday reasoning, etc.) may legitimately use different logical systems.
